Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Easy-to-Use Software for Automation Integration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project can dramatically transform the population of people to whom automation, and its well-documented benefits, is available. The lack of tools targeted at truly nontechnical users that still have the aspiration to be practically useful (rather than educational in nature) is a barrier to many. The approach taken in this proposal could reduce or remove this barrier and bring simple, moving machines into many more environments. For hobbyists, this means increased ability to self-design the logical behavior of the machines and simple devices already being created in this group. For small to medium sized businesses, this may mean increased productivity, quality, and revenue, particularly for small-batch processes. Further into the future, this technology can be applied to home automation where it is critical for society that all users have control over the behavior of their connected devices, particularly in such a personal space where social and cultural considerations require individual customization to design how the "smart" things around the home move.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has two main objectives. First, the computational scalability of an initial, proof-of concept prototype will be tested. Technical hurdles for this objective include the development of a scalable code architecture and support for a larger number of so-called sensing and action primitives, which will be explained in the proposal. Second, the ability of an untrained user to move from a contextualized use-case to specific logic design will be determined. Technical hurdles for this objective are in the domain of human factors, where a relatively complex process must be distilled to essential steps that an untrained user can relate to a familiar process in a particular environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AE Machines empowers manufacturers and hobbyists to program and reprogram simple automated systems without relying on the help of engineers.

This Phase I award tested the feasibility of a novel prototype developed as a result of the co-founders’, one of whom is a university faculty member and robotics researcher, work with a small business to implement a simple automated system.  The system AE has built is predicated on a simple, key technological approach: we work from a top-down movement abstraction and build the necessary low-level architecture needed to realize the high-level function. This is accomplished through an interdisciplinary team approach combining computer science, robotics expertise, and movement-based abstractions to build a web-based, easy-to-use platform.  Prior to the start of the award AE Machines had built an initial prototype, which was redesigned, improved, and tested with novice (nontechnical) users over the last year, during this Phase I award.

The AE Design Tool (www.aemachines.com and www.aemachines.io) has been live since October of 2016 and has been continually improved due to the funding from this grant.  The tool abstracts the tedious process of programming a microcontroller. The tool allows users with no coding or hardware experience to build and program an automated cell.  Eventually, if funding for expanded development is secured, industrial hardware like multi-link robot manipulators and conveyor belts will be supported.    

The team has also received some attention from visitors to our incubator, including from Adam Hecktman, Microsoft’s Director of Technology and Civic Innovation for Chicago who said:

“…A drag and drop design interface so that the young and non-technical can have fun learning about the internet of things. It will truly broaden the opportunity for the Internet of Things…”

The team hopes to capitalize on this initial interest in our platform by creating buzz using our maker-oriented site and our recently announced partnership with MakeCrate, a company that sells educationally-oriented hardware kits for Arduino, who packages the AE Design Tool alongside their hardware kits.  While the tool support users within the Maker community we will continue to build the tool for more industrial applications.  The tool built in this award is, at the time of this report, a finalist for Product Design of the Year at the Fourth Revolution Awards, which celebrate innovation in manufacturing in the Chicago region.

  

Intellectual Merit: First, the computational scalability of an initial, proof-of concept prototype was tested.  Technical hurdles for this objective included the development of a scalable code architecture and support for a larger number of so-called sensing and action primitives.  We addressed this issue by creating our own rules engine that allowed the compiler that supported varying part and primitive structures.  Most notably, our prototype supports primitives that required more than one part, parts that required more than one port, sequential and simultaneous control structures, and many to many sense / action relationships.  Due to these improvements, our newly developed and launched prototype supports 3 microcontrollers (Arduino Uno, Arduino Leonardo, and littleBits Arduino), 20 parts and 38 primitives.  Second, the ability of an untrained user to move from a contextualized use-case to specific logic design was determined.  We tested this objective by performing three series of user tests.  In all three rounds users were successfully able to design machines that addressed the issues laid out in a “word problems”.  These tests also indicated to us different parts of the design process and documentation on the site that needed to be addressed, including the addition of a part or primitive to the machine being uniform between the hardware and software design areas (so that users could build “left-to-right” or “right-to-left”, the contents of the help pages, the need of an overview video explaining how the site works, and a parts and primitive glossary.

 

Broader/Commercial Impact: The work done during the Phase I has the potential to dramatically transform the population of people to whom automation, and its well-documented benefits, is available.  The lack of tools targeted at nontechnical users that have the aspiration to be practically useful – rather than educational in nature – is a barrier to many.  The feasibility of our approach, both technical scalability and ease of use, has been proven out through our prototype and the user-studies we performed.  For hobbyists, this means increased ability to self-design the logical behavior of the machines and simple devices already being created in this group.  Further into the future, with sufficient funding, this technology can be scaled to industrial, manufacturing applications.  Flexible automation cells are particularly needed in small-batch processes, which change week-to-week or day-to-day, that can be powered by our software.  In this context, our tool has the potential to allow workers currently on the factory floor to be able to manage and automate factory lines with skills they already have, creating “middle-skilled” jobs needed in an advanced manufacturing economy.
